author: sky.cactus
content: I believe Capella is the name of the CL fork, and without a paired EL fork then withdraws functionally won't be enabled still.  The CL has planned for a while to include withdraws in Capella, but it wasn't until very recently that there was actual discussion about Shanghai with the EL devs.  In theory, withdraws could be implemented in Capella without users actually being able to withdraw anything (I'm personally a fan of this as it means we successfully separated EL/CL forks).

author: sky.cactus
content: I agree that withdraws need to be enabled eventually.  The question isn't "are withdraws good", it is "are withdraws more important than anything else we could possibly be working on".  The answer may be yes, or it might not be.  At the time I made the referenced comments we had not had that discussion yet, which is why I was concerned that people were announcing withdraw implementation timelines.

author: sky.cactus
content: We should *always* first decide what we (as a group) consider most important, then we should implement it, then we should release it, then we should announce it.  We shouldn't announce first, then release, then discuss.

author: sky.cactus
content: Ethereum has two parts to it now.  Execution Layer (EL) and Consensus Layer (CL).  IIUC, Capella is the name of the upcoming CL hard fork.  Shanghai is the name of the upcoming EL hardfork.  Withdraws require changes to both EL and CL.  If the CL implements some changes to enable withdraws but the EL doesn't implement their side, then withdraws won't *functionally* be implemented in any meaningful way.  They'll be "half done", but waiting on the EL still.

author: sky.cactus
content: Personally, I think the EL should be implemented first, and then the CL can implement their changes in a future hard fork.  However, I think a lot of people want to try to release EL and CL changes at the same time (same block).
